awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Alaskan perspective on middle Paleozoic terrane translation,  contraction, and subduction initiation in northwestern Laurentia
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental concept in plate tectonics is that ancient continental margins undergo a conversion process from “passive” zones of sediment accumulation to “active” zones dominated by subduction, volcanism, and mountain building. The process by which this transition occurs is through subduction initiation along continental margins. However, modern examples and numerical models of subduction initiation remain highly contentious. The late Paleozoic (ca. 450–300 million years ago) conversion of northwestern North America from a passive to an active margin is often cited as a classic example of this fundamental plate tectonic process, but very little is known about the nature and timing of key events in northern Alaska and Yukon, Canada, that led to this subduction initiation event. This study promotes collaboration between academic researchers at three U.S. institutions and government researchers at the United States Geological Survey (USGS) to better inform our understanding of late Paleozoic tectonic events in a remote and understudied region of North America. A diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students will participate in research initiatives at each institution. In addition, the research team will collaborate with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the USGS to disseminate geologic knowledge of Arctic Alaska to the public, to enhance the economic competitiveness of the U.S. and facilitate the training of the next generation of Arctic Earth scientists.

Recent models for the middle Paleozoic tectonic evolution of North America (Laurentia) highlight margin-parallel transport of circum-Arctic terranes followed by widespread continental subduction initiation from the Yukon to Nevada. However, the timing, nature, and duration of middle Paleozoic orogenic events remain ambiguous. This project will focus on key structural relationships and unique Devonian–Carboniferous synorogenic sedimentary and magmatic rocks within the Arctic Alaska terrane of northern Alaska. The research consists of three major components: 1) the examination of synorogenic rocks coupled with the development of a regional provenance dataset; 2) a petrological, geochemical, and geochronological examination of regional Middle to Upper Devonian igneous rocks; and 3) a field-based structural study integrated with regional seismic datasets to reconstruct the style of Devonian–Carboniferous deformation in Arctic Alaska. This work will provide critical new insights into the Paleozoic tectonic evolution of northwestern North America and the greater circum-Arctic region to assess the viability of several subduction initiation mechanisms. In addition, this project will provide new piercing points for Mesozoic tectonic reconstructions of the Arctic, with relevance to several subdisciplines of the geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: 204 W. Wash. St., Dept. of Geology, Washington and Lee University

por.por_cntn:
The project centered on improving the understanding the Devonian-Carboniferous tectonic history of Arctic Alaska. Specifically, the work involved the dating and mapping of sedimentary and igneous Devonian-Carboniferous rocks exposed in the central and northeast Brooks Range, and untangling this deformation from later mountain-building events. A second major research vein was determining the timing, and structural styles of tectonic events in the Devonian-Carboniferous in the subsurface, north of the Brooks Range, in the North Slope and adjacent offshore.  In support of the project, fieldwork was completed in 2021-2023 and seismic interpretation was conducted in 2020-2024. 

The primary research outcomes of the work conducted at Washington and Lee University in collaboration with researchers at the University of Iowa, Dartmouth College, and the U. S Geological Survey include:

1)      Paleozoic fold-and-thrust belts in the subsurface of Arctic Alaska and the adjacent offshore Beaufort Shelf display ubiquitous Devonian and possibly earlier contractional deformation.  They generally trend east-west (present-day coordinates), with a complex interplay of north and south directed transport and vergence directions.  Local shortening continued into the Mississippian and probably the Pennsylvanian.  Late Paleozoic crustal extension on the North Slope is not extensive, and likely related to minor strain accommodation.

2)      In the Chukchi Shelf a detached, an east-directed fold-and-thrust belt developed, likely in the Early Devonian.  Carboniferous extensional collapse of the previous orogenic belt to form the Hanna Trough was influenced heterogeneously by pre-Mississippian contractional fabrics.

3)      These subsurface structural relationships indicate a more complex late Paleozoic tectonic history than previously recognized for Arctic Alaska and the adjacent offshore region.  

The project resulted in significant scientific collaboration between Washington and Lee University and two other academic institutions (the University of Iowa and Dartmouth College), as well as with the U. S. Geological Survey, and resulted in 8 public presentations at conferences and one peer-reviewed manuscript.  The project provided significant opportunity to train STEM students.  The project involved 8 undergraduate students, and resulted in two undergraduate student theses at Washington and Lee University.  Mentoring and collaboration with several undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Iowa and Dartmouth College also occurred.   Beneficial outreach resulted from teaching K-12 students in a native community in Arctic Alaska about scientific field observations, maps, and rocks and minerals.  An educational pamphlet was developed on the bedrock geology of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for the Fish and Wildlife Service. This was intended to be something that will be handed out to visitors to the Refuge.

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2024
Modified by: Christopher D Connors
